job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The work is always focused on how to help individuals we serve. I never feel pressure to focus on dollars instead of providing compassionate care. There are opportunities to grow within the company. Good retirement matching benefits.
cons: We are only in santa clara county!

review_title: Good Place to Work, Toxic Colleagues
job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Staff is hard-working and care about their clients Upper management is supportive if you ask for feedback/suggestions Good pay for a non-profit Good benefits, even if it's Kaiser Some teams are like family and care about each other, super supportive and willing to help others Multidisciplinary team and consultation opportunities
cons: Training new staff is non-existent, no standard training procedure Toxic managers who don't know what they are doing or how to treat staff respectfully Petty manager who doesn't know what they are actually doing and rely on their assistant manager to complete all the tasks High turnover, likely due to poor management Very demanding, high standards of care

job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great employees who are extremely dedicated to the well-being of clients.
cons: Zero support from Upper Management. Top-down system. Upper management was being carried by middle management without any gratitude or respect.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in San Jose, CA
pros: Good benefits, managers that don’t micromanage, quarterly bonuses if the program exceeds productivity for the month, pretty good vacation, sick leave, and flexibility.
cons: New staff training can be improved for using their EHR system, documentation, and administrative tasks that needs to be completed as part of the role.

job_title: Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: They're a great organization and I love working there
cons: The wages are nonprofit so they're low

review_title: No accountability for leaders with problematic history
job_title: Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Many Momentum staff are hardworking, compassionate, and dedicated to clients and the mission.

Pay for managers is good compared to other nonprofits, however, pay for entry level positions is poor.
cons:
Open door policy is not effective in addressing problematic leadership. HR does not address leaders with a problematic history or hold them accountable for toxic behavior. Instead, staff with a grievance against their supervisors are viewed as the problem. Current Development leadership is problematic and has been the cause of recent staff turnover. Anyone looking for a role in Marketing under the current Development leadership should beware. 

There is a disconnect between staff and leadership. All-Staff and Managers meetings are inconsistent and could be used as an opportunity for leadership and/or managers to connect with staff in a meaningful way and cultivate a culture of transparency. 

Infrastructure at Momentum could use much more capacity. Facilities and IT teams are small and have to support a staff of 500 spread out over many locations. Overall, processes are slow at Momentum and there is a lack of clarity around which roles own specific tasks.

job_title: Clinician I in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Not working there anymore was the best part of working there.
cons: Incompetent and burnt out management

job_title: Staff Accountant in San Jose, CA
pros: People are nice and helpful. Management is flexible. There are great benefits.
cons: Sometimes you get more responsibility than what is stated on your job description.

job_title: Clinician in San Jose, CA
pros: Good work life balance. Supportive management.
cons: It can get very busy depending on how many intakes in a given day.

job_title: Clinician I in San Jose, CA
pros: Best parts of this job was working with clients with psychosis, addictions and other severe mental health disorders. I learned a lot about the mental health system as a whole. Additionally the other clinicians were wonderful to work with and helped me through every step of the way. Thank god for them.
cons: My manager was extremely narcissistic, unrealistic, unsupportive and created a hostile work environment. I did not feel safe at my workplace I was constantly harassed, and humiliated during team meetings. When I reported her to management nothing was done instead everything got worse. HR did nothing for me except stir the pot with her and she began to treat me even more poorly by attacking my character and work ethic etc. additionally this job is not what it is said to be, you will be exhausted, burnout and forget about why you even decided to go into mental health in the first place. The pay is good but it was not worth suffering for me. If you like being overworked and burnout this is the place for you, the work never ends and you will feel incompetent. Clinicians are expected to pick up everyone on the teams slack and are never seen as humans who deserve empathy or a goddamn break. During my time here I saw 5 people leave my team because of the manager. I was the 6th person to leave in less than a years time frame.

review_title: Combination of therapy with clients and clinical oversight of case managers
job_title: Clinician II in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility and variety; much direct service with clients; long-term therapy with clients; team environment
cons: High turnover rate of clinical staff; management overly focused on productivity and not clinically trained

job_title: Clinician II in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good people to work with
Good benefits
cons:
Burnout definitely happens
Clientele can be challenging to work with

job_title: IPS Employment Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: It is a Great Culture
cons: I cannot think of any cons

job_title: Case Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The coworkers are a huge reason I've been able to grow and remain in this field; we are each other's biggest support. The workplace has an atmosphere of collaboration and inclusion. Of course working with clients is hugely fulfilling and is the reason I'm in this field to begin with.
cons: It is VERY difficult to advance or get promoted without a master's degree (LCSW, MFT, LMFT, etc.) and the expectations from the county to meet productivity can be stifling. You have to make peace with lots of paperwork and MediCal billing.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Jose, CA
pros:
People really care about the clients. 
The managers are great and care about their employees.
The pay is good.
The company is unionized so there are great benefits.
cons:
There is a lot of required documentations.
Caseloads can get very high. 
There is a lot of burnout and overturn of staff.

job_title: Bridge Services Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: Ability to work independently on case management
cons: Working within constraints of the American health system

job_title: Crisis Residential Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: -Great hands on experience for this field
cons: -Can be stressful at times

review_title: Middle management like the Catholic Church
job_title: Crisis Residential Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros:
Coworkers are great. Close knit teams.
Client interactions are rewarding, and you learn an incredible amount. 
Almost unlimited county linked training if it's relevant to your role.
Excellent benefits and the best pay for this field in this area.
Unionized positions for direct care staff.
cons:
No formal qualifications for managers.

Some of middle managers don't understand basic concepts like: don't micromanage, inspire enthusiasm in your employees, respect your employees intelligence/experience/qualifications, don't deliberately and obviously favor certain employees and hold others to unrealistic and contradictory standards.

Don't create environments that feel so hostile employees choose to leave.

Some managers create a hostile work environment leading to HR complaints, union assistance  and cases, and inevitably turnover of employees lacking support.

HR has protected this behavior from managers for 30+ years in every previous organization that MMH has evolved into. It's like the Catholic Church - when one manager (like a priest) causes "too many problems", they (HR) simply transfer them to another work site, rather than addressing the systemic issues at hand. This attitude drives away valuable employees.

job_title: Personal Services Coordinator in San Jose, CA
pros: Great pay and excellent benefits.
cons: No downsides that I could think of.

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Flexibility. Fulfilling work. Tx plans & assessments.
cons: I don’t really have any cons.

job_title: Crisis Residential Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: Gives you great experience for your resume & pays better than most companies.
cons: Burn out easily, & sometimes feels like you're just a cog in the machine

job_title: Clinician in San Jose, CA
pros: Clinical supervision is included in position (both group and individual), supportive team, great training opportunities, pay is above average for mental health CBOs, annual increases, realistic work expectations.
cons: Clinicians are placed in leadership role while still being union employees (creates tension on teams as clinicians are expected to set limits with staff but have no follow trough). Dependent/spouse health insurance coverage is not affordable, union representation (stewards) are extremely negative and not willing to work with anyone outside of their own interests.

job_title: Clinician I in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good Benefits, nice pay, great co-workers. Great for accumulating hours, supervision included, over time opportunity. Freedom in therapeutic approach with appointed clients. Nice location- Stanford area of Palo alto
cons: Understaffed, no job training but still expected to perform, managers reluctant to provide training other than worksheets. supervisors lie about being supportive, and difficult to set aside time to meet with to address needs. Manager became hostile at the end. Worked right up until my 6 month probation then fired. Clinical Director's ego/anger difficulties affect working environment. No office space

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Employees gain a wealth of experience working with those who've been diagnosed with severe and persistent mental illness. Wrap-around services support clients in rehabilitation, and, in general, fellow coworkers are extremely supportive.
cons:
Secretive and vindictive management. Executive management has little clue of what front-line employees deal with on a day-to-day basis. Management, in general, are not collaborative, and are often jealous of their employees strengths. Momentum is an extremely top-heavy organization that could benefit from cost-cutting measures by laying off management. 
Momentum management is not well respected throughout the county and for good reason.

review_title: Job title all that i apply
job_title: Program Director/Physical Therapist in San Jose, CA
pros: Working as a doctor at momentum help me gain the skills i need to get by applying it everyday. I gain confidence now i enjoy my life more with the friends at momentum
cons: Professionally i would like to go beyond case mangement as a mentor. I take my time, patients, and attention to work with our clients. i have to share cases with other doctors because i cant get to all of them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Options for growth into a variety of career paths
- Dedicated staff/team to providing effective services to clients/community
- Agency provides multiple levels of care to clients of diverse backgrounds
- Good benefits/compensation for employees for a non-profit company
- Multiple program locations offer different candidates options to work at most convenient sites (to avoid commute, etc.)
- Very diverse group of employees in agency (language, ethnic background, etc.)
cons:
- Due to size of the agency, there are occasions when decisions can take a while before it is made/confirmed
- Closed Shop (union) can be something that can potentially detract candidates, for those not interested in union shops

job_title: Program Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Great culture and dedicated staff.  Lots of opportunity for growth and development including upward mobility.  Support for ongoing education and individual professional growth. Excellent benefits. Broad scope of services offered and lots of different programs.  Dedicated to to being a leader in its field and takes a proactive and forward thinking approach to the company's direction
cons: There are no easy jobs and the expectations for professionalism is high.  Competitiveness of compensation package for highly experiences staff is poor relative to some other employers and this agency is limited in its ability to address this.

job_title: Clinician in San Jose, CA
pros: Good benefits, decent pay, Union benefits (sort of). Nice supportive coworkers passionate about helping clients. Great clients to get experience with, collect hours with supervision.
cons: No training for new hires. Unmanageable work load, always increasing the load, expected to get things done regardless of time barriers. Union is useless, management is not afraid of Union concerns. Only favorite employees get promoted. Executive team paid well and get fat bonuses while staff struggle to even get COLA annual raises. Upper management doesn't care about staff or even clients, they just want to boost their own incomes. Clients not treated well, their concerns about treatment aren't important to management.

job_title: Clinician I, in Bethlehem, PA
pros: you will gain great experience working in the mental health field. opportunity to work with some talented people. excellent benefits. lots of room to grow and promote. there are a variety of programs and you can transfer between them to gain a variety of experience
cons: some of the people who work there are just there for the paycheck and/or are not all that intelligent. That can be frustrating when trying to collaborate.

review_title: Momentum is and employer of choice
job_title: Residential Program Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Momentum has been a great place to learn and grow as both a clinician and a manager.  The salaries are competitive and the culture is positive.  There is much opportunity to promote with hard work and dedication.
cons: I don't really have any cons to offer.  Helping individuals is hard work and self care is essential.

job_title: Associate Director & Administrator in San Jose, CA
pros: Dedicated to improving the lives of people with Mental Health issues; supporting them to be productive members of society & ensuring they receive the treatment needed to achieve that.
cons: Situated in Silicone Valley which makes it difficult for staff due to high cost of living.

review_title: Non-Profit which is run like a For Profit company.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Well, there are always job openings and there are several locations or job sites to choose from.  There is some level of stability in the case manager positions and an average benefits package.
cons: Weird management philosophy for a medical agency - they strongly overemphasize and encourage patient care interventions which have little evidence to support effectiveness in treating mental illness (rather extreme take on the social rehab approach to patient care).  I left due to aggressive and questionable billing practices.

review_title: Great place to get supervision, MFTI hours, great team.
job_title: Clinician I in Palo Alto, CA

cons: Evening/weekend hours may be required, work can be challenging but colleagues, manager, supervisor were all very supportive.
